A Few Good Men (play).label: A Few Good Men
A Few Good Men (play).description: A Few Good Men is a play by Aaron Sorkin, first produced on Broadway by David Brown in 1989. It tells the story of military lawyers at a court-martial who uncover a high-level conspiracy in the course ... Wikipedia

Amphitryon (play).label: Amphitryon
Amphitryon (play).description: Amphitryon is a Latin play for the early Roman theatre by playwright Titus Maccius Plautus. It is Plautus’ only play on a mythological subject; he refers to it as a tragicomoedia in the prologue. Wikipedia

Andromaque.label: Andromaque
Andromaque.description: Andromaque is a tragedy in five acts by the French playwright Jean Racine written in alexandrine verse. Wikipedia

Anna Christie.label: Anna Christie
Anna Christie.description: Anna Christie is a play in four acts by Eugene O'Neill. It made its Broadway debut at the Vanderbilt Theatre on November 2, 1921. O'Neill received the 1922 Pulitzer Prize for Drama for this work. Wikipedia

Electra (Sophocles).label: Electra
Electra (Sophocles).description: Electra or Elektra is a Greek tragedy by Sophocles. Its date is not known, but various stylistic similarities with the Philoctetes and the Oedipus at Colonus lead scholars to suppose that it was written towards the end of Sophocles' career. Wikipedia

Equus (play).label: Equus
Equus (play).description: Equus is a play by Peter Shaffer written in 1973, telling the story of a psychiatrist who attempts to treat a young man who has a pathological religious fascination with horses. Wikipedia

Heartbreak House.label: Heartbreak House
Heartbreak House.description: Heartbreak House A Fantasia in the Russian Manner on English Themes is a play written by George Bernard Shaw, first published in 1919 and first played at the New York's Garrick Theatre in 1920. Wikipedia

Everyman (play).label: Everyman
Everyman (play).description: The Somonyng of Everyman, usually referred to simply as Everyman, is a late 15th-century English morality play. Wikipedia

Herakles (Euripides).label: Herakles
Herakles (Euripides).description: Herakles is an Athenian tragedy by Euripides that was first performed c. 416 BCE. While Herakles is in the underworld obtaining Cerberus for one of his labours, his father Amphitryon, wife Megara, and ... Wikipedia

Hippolytus (play).label: Hippolytus
Hippolytus (play).description: Hippolytus is an Ancient Greek tragedy by Euripides, based on the myth of Hippolytus, son of Theseus. The play was first produced for the City Dionysia of Athens in 428 BC and won first prize as part of a trilogy. Wikipedia

I Am My Own Wife.label: I Am My Own Wife
I Am My Own Wife.description: I Am My Own Wife is a play by Doug Wright based on his conversations with German Charlotte von Mahlsdorf. The one-man play premiered Off-Broadway in 2003 at Playwrights Horizons. It opened on Broadway later that year. Wikipedia

Life of Galileo.label: Life of Galileo
Life of Galileo.description: Life of Galileo, also known as Galileo, is a play by the twentieth-century German dramatist Bertolt Brecht with incidental music by Hanns Eisler. Wikipedia

Noises Off.label: Noises Off
Noises Off.description: Noises Off is a 1982 play by the English playwright Michael Frayn. The idea for it came in 1970, when Frayn was watching from the wings a performance of The Two of Us, a farce that he had written for Lynn Redgrave. Wikipedia

Oedipus (Voltaire).label: Oedipus
Oedipus (Voltaire).description: Oedipus is a tragedy by the French dramatist and philosopher Voltaire that was first performed in 1718. It was his first play and the first literary work for which he used the pen-name Voltaire. Wikipedia

Oedipus at Colonus.label: Oedipus at Colonus
Oedipus at Colonus.description: Oedipus at Colonus is one of the three Theban plays of the Athenian tragedian Sophocles. It was written shortly before Sophocles' death in 406 BC and produced by his grandson at the Festival of Dionysus in 401 BC. Wikipedia

Peer Gynt.label: Peer Gynt
Peer Gynt.description: Peer Gynt is a five-act play in verse by the Norwegian dramatist Henrik Ibsen. Written in the Bokmål form of Norwegian, it is one of the most widely performed Norwegian plays. Wikipedia

Philoctetes (Sophocles).label: Philoctetes
Philoctetes (Sophocles).description: Philoctetes is a play by Sophocles. The play was written during the Peloponnesian War. It was first performed at the Festival of Dionysus in 409 BC, where it won first prize. The story takes place during the Trojan War. Wikipedia

Proof (play).label: Proof
Proof (play).description: Proof is a 2000 play by the American playwright David Auburn. Premiered Off-Broadway in May 2000, it transferred to Broadway theater in October 2000. The production closed in January 2003 after a total of 917 performances. Wikipedia

Shibaraku.label: Shibaraku
Shibaraku.description: Shibaraku is among the most popular pieces in the Kabuki repertoire, and one of the celebrated Kabuki Jūhachiban. Wikipedia

The Great White Hope.label: The Great White Hope
The Great White Hope.description: The Great White Hope is a 1967 play written by Howard Sackler, later adapted in 1970 for a film of the same name. Wikipedia

The Invention of Love.label: The Invention of Love
The Invention of Love.description: The Invention of Love is a 1997 play by Tom Stoppard portraying the life of poet A. E. Housman, focusing specifically on his personal life and love for a college classmate. Wikipedia

The Investigation (play).label: The Investigation
The Investigation (play).description: The Investigation is a play by Peter Weiss written in 1965 which depicts the Frankfurt Auschwitz Trials of 1963-1965. It premiered on October 19, 1965 on stages in fourteen West and East German cities and at the Royal Shakespeare Company in London. Wikipedia
Author: Peter Weiss

The Lady from the Sea.label: The Lady from the Sea
The Lady from the Sea.description: The Lady from the Sea is a play written in 1888 by Norwegian playwright Henrik Ibsen. Wikipedia

The Trojan Women.label: The Trojan Women
The Trojan Women.description: The Trojan Women, also known as Troades, is a tragedy by the Greek playwright Euripides. Produced in 415 BC during the Peloponnesian War, it is often considered a commentary on the capture of the Aegean ... Wikipedia

The Wasps.label: The Wasps
The Wasps.description: The Wasps is the fourth in chronological order of the eleven surviving plays by Aristophanes, the master of an ancient genre of drama called 'Old Comedy'. Wikipedia

Three Sisters (play).label: Three Sisters
Three Sisters (play).description: Three Sisters is a play by the Russian author and playwright Anton Chekhov, perhaps partially inspired by the situation of the three Brontë sisters. It was written in 1900 and first performed in 1901 at the Moscow Art Theatre. Wikipedia

Trinummus.label: Trinummus
Trinummus.description: Trinummus is a comedic Latin play by the early Roman playwright Titus Maccius Plautus. Wikipedia

A Disappearing Number.label: A Disappearing Number
A Disappearing Number.description: A Disappearing Number is a 2007 play co-written and devised by the Théâtre de Complicité company and directed and conceived by English playwright Simon McBurney. Wikipedia

Electra (Euripides).label: Electra
Electra (Euripides).description: Euripides' Electra was a play probably written in the mid 410s BC, likely after 413 BC. It is unclear whether it was first produced before or after Sophocles' version of the Electra story. Wikipedia

Aulularia.label: Aulularia
Aulularia.description: Aulularia is a Latin play by the early Roman playwright Titus Maccius Plautus. The title has been translated as The Pot of Gold, and the plot revolves around a literal pot of gold which the miserly protagonist, Euclio, guards zealously. Wikipedia

Lysistrata.label: Lysistrata
Lysistrata.description: Lysistrata is a comedy by Aristophanes. Originally performed in classical Athens in 411 BC, it is a comic account of one woman's extraordinary mission to end the Peloponnesian War. Wikipedia

Life is a Dream.label: Life Is a Dream
Life is a Dream.description: Life Is a Dream is a Spanish-language play by Pedro Calderón de la Barca. First published in 1635, it is a philosophical allegory regarding the human situation and the mystery of life. Wikipedia

Medea (play).label: Medea
Medea (play).description: Medea is an ancient Greek tragedy written by Euripides, based upon the myth of Jason and Medea and first produced in 431 BC. Wikipedia
Adaptations: freely adapted from the Medea of EuripidesMore

Oedipus the King.label: Oedipus the King
Oedipus the King.description: Oedipus the King, also known by the Latin title Oedipus Rex, is an Athenian tragedy by Sophocles that was first performed c. 429 BC. Wikipedia

Pseudolus.label: Pseudolus
Pseudolus.description: Pseudolus is a play by the ancient Roman playwright Titus Maccius Plautus. It is one of the earliest examples of Roman literature. Wikipedia
Adaptations: A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum

Seven Against Thebes.label: Seven Against Thebes
Seven Against Thebes.description: The Seven against Thebes is the third play in an Oedipus-themed trilogy produced by Aeschylus in 467 BC. The trilogy is sometimes referred to as the Oedipodea. Wikipedia

The Acharnians.label: The Acharnians
The Acharnians.description: The Acharnians or Acharnians is the third play — and the earliest of the eleven surviving plays — by the Athenian playwright Aristophanes. Wikipedia

The Clouds.label: The Clouds
The Clouds.description: The Clouds is a comedy written by the celebrated playwright Aristophanes lampooning intellectual fashions in classical Athens. Wikipedia

The Trickster of Seville and the Stone G.label: The Trickster of Seville and the Stone Guest
The Trickster of Seville and the Stone G.description: The Seducer of Seville and the Stone Guest is a play by Tirso de Molina, first published in Spain around 1630, though it may have been performed as early as 1616. Wikipedia

The Triumph of Love.label: The Triumph of Love
The Triumph of Love.description: The Triumph of Love is a 2001 romantic comedy film, based on Marivaux's 1732 play of the same name. It was directed by Clare Peploe, produced by her husband Bernardo Bertolucci, and stars Mira Sorvino and Ben Kingsley. Wikipedia

Mogadishu (play).label: Mogadishu
Mogadishu (play).description: Mogadishu is the debut play by ex-school teacher Vivienne Franzmann concerning a white teacher who tries to protect her black student from expulsion after he pushes her to the ground. Wikipedia

A Night in November.label: A night in November
A Night in November.description: A Night in November is a 1994 monodrama written by Marie Jones about one man's struggle with national identity during The Troubles in Northern Ireland. Wikipedia
Author: Marie Jones

A Perfect Ganesh.label: A Perfect Ganesh
A Perfect Ganesh.description: A Perfect Ganesh is a play written by Terrance McNally in 1993. The play follows the life of two very rich, middle-aged women, Margaret Civil and Katherine Brynne, who struggle with the concept of inner peace. Wikipedia

A Provincial Lady.label: Diary of a Provincial Lady
A Provincial Lady.description: With a cover design by Cath KidstonBehind this rather prim and proper title lies the hilarious fictional diary of a long-suffering, disaster-prone Devon lady of the 1930s, and her attempts to keep her ... Google Books
Author: E. M. Delafield

Bosoms and Neglect.label: Bosoms and Neglect
Bosoms and Neglect.description: Bosoms and Neglect is a play by American playwright John Guare, first staged in 1979 at the Goodman Theatre in Chicago, Illinois. Wikipedia

Each In His Own Way.label: Each in his own way
Each In His Own Way.description: Each In His Own Way is a 1924 play by Luigi Pirandello. Like his more famous Six Characters in Search of an Author, it forms part of his "trilogy of the theatre in the theatre." Wikipedia
Author: Luigi Pirandello

Ruined (play).label: Ruined
Ruined (play).description: Ruined is a play by Lynn Nottage. The play won the 2009 Pulitzer Prize for Drama. The play involves the plight of women in the civil war-torn Democratic Republic of Congo. Wikipedia

Enough Stupidity in Every Wise Man.label: Enough Stupidity in Every Wise Man
Enough Stupidity in Every Wise Man.description: Enough Stupidity in Every Wise Man is a five-act comedy by Aleksandr Ostrovsky. The play offers a satirical treatment of bigotry and charts the rise of a double-dealer who manipulates other people's vanities. Wikipedia

The Eve of St. Mark.label: The Eve of St. Mark
The Eve of St. Mark.description: The Eve of St Mark is a 1942 play by Maxwell Anderson set during World War II. It later became a 1944 film by 20th Century Fox that featured some of the same actors who repeated their roles in the film. Wikipedia

The Phoney Civilization.label: The Phoney Civilization
The Phoney Civilization.description: The Phoney Civilization is a satirical TV musical released in 1974 by the Bulgarian National Television, directed by Hacho Boyadzhiev, starring Georgi Partsalev, Georgi Kaloyanchev, Ruzha Delcheva, ... Wikipedia

The Second Shepherds' Play.label: The Second Shepherds' Play
The Second Shepherds' Play.description: The Second Shepherds' Play is a famous medieval mystery play which is contained in the manuscript HM1, the unique manuscript of the Wakefield Cycle. Wikipedia

Water by the Spoonful.label: Water by the Spoonful
Water by the Spoonful.description: Water by the Spoonful is a play by Quiara Alegría Hudes. It won the 2012 Pulitzer Prize for Drama. Hudes had previously won the 2008 Tony Award for Best Musical for In the Heights. Wikipedia

I Hate Hamlet.label: I Hate Hamlet
I Hate Hamlet.description: I Hate Hamlet is a dramatic comedy written in 1991 by Paul Rudnick. Set in John Barrymore's old apartment in New York City - at the time, the author's real-life home - the play follows successful ... Wikipedia

In Arabia We'd All Be Kings.label: In Arabia We'd All Be Kings
In Arabia We'd All Be Kings.description: In Arabia We'd All Be Kings is a dramatic play set in New York City, written by Stephen Adly Guirgis. Wikipedia

Kiss and Tell (play).label: Kiss and Tell
Kiss and Tell (play).description:
Kiss and Tell is a 1943 Broadway play by F. Hugh Herbert.
Kiss and Tell starred Betty Caulfield as Corliss Archer. The families portrayed within the play are the Archer, Franklin, and Pringle families. Wikipedia

A Marriage Proposal.label: A Marriage Proposal
A Marriage Proposal.description: A Marriage Proposal is a one-act farce by Anton Chekhov, written in 1888-1889 and first performed in 1890. It is a fast-paced play of dialogue-based action and situational humour. Wikipedia

Angel City (play).label: Angel City
Angel City (play).description: Angel City is a play by Sam Shepard. Wikipedia

Bacchides (play).label: Bacchides
Bacchides (play).description: Bacchides is a Latin play by the early Roman playwright Titus Maccius Plautus. The title has been translated as The Bacchises, and the plot revolves around the misunderstandings surrounding two sisters, ... Wikipedia

Bug (play).label: Bug
Bug (play).description: Bug is a play by American playwright Tracy Letts. It was adapted into a film in 2006, with Letts writing the screenplay and Michael Shannon reprising his role as Peter. Wikipedia

Camino Real (play).label: Camino Real
Camino Real (play).description: Camino Real is a 1953 play by Tennessee Williams. In the introduction to the Penguin edition of the play, Williams directs the reader to use the Anglicized pronunciation "Cá-mino Réal." Wikipedia

California Suite.label: California Suite
California Suite.description: California Suite is a 1978 American comedy film directed by Herbert Ross. The screenplay by Neil Simon is based on his play of the same title. Wikipedia
Characters: Pilot in Diana Barrie's Film on Airplane

Charlie Victor Romeo.label: Charlie Victor Romeo
Charlie Victor Romeo.description: Charlie Victor Romeo is a 1999 play whose script consists of almost-verbatim transcripts from six real aviation accidents and incidents. Wikipedia

Deathtrap (play).label: Deathtrap
Deathtrap (play).description: Deathtrap is a play by Ira Levin in 1978 with many plot twists and references itself as a play within a play. It is in two acts with one set and five characters. Wikipedia

Da (play).label: Da
Da (play).description:
Da is a 1978 comedy play by Irish playwright Hugh Leonard.
The play had its New York City premiere at the off-off-Broadway Hudson Guild Theatre in 1978, and this production transferred to Broadway shortly after the completion of its run. Wikipedia

Dido, Queen of Carthage.label: Dido
Dido, Queen of Carthage.description: Dido was, according to ancient Greek and Roman sources, the founder and first Queen of Carthage. She is best known from the account given by the Roman poet Virgil in his Aeneid. In some sources she is also known as Elissa. Wikipedia

Electra (Giraudoux).label: Electra
Electra (Giraudoux).description: Electra is a two act play written in 1937 by French dramatist Jean Giraudoux. It was the first Giraudoux play to employ the staging of Louis Jouvet. Based on the classic myth of antiquity, Jean Giraudoux wrote perhaps his best play. Wikipedia
Author: Jean Giraudoux

Entertaining Mr Sloane.label: Entertaining Mr Sloane
Entertaining Mr Sloane.description: Entertaining Mr Sloane is a play by the English playwright Joe Orton. It was first produced in London at the New Arts Theatre on 6 May 1964 and transferred to the West End's Wyndham's Theatre on 29 June 1964. Wikipedia

FOB (play).label: FOB
FOB (play).description: FOB is a 1980 Obie Award-winning play by American playwright David Henry Hwang. Hwang's first play, it depicts the contrasts and conflicts between established Asian Americans and "fresh off the boat" newcomer immigrants. Wikipedia

Fences (play).label: Fences
Fences (play).description: Fences is a 1983 play by American playwright August Wilson. Set in the 1950s, it is the sixth in Wilson's ten-part Pittsburgh Cycle. Wikipedia

Doctor Faustus (play).label: The Tragical History of the Life and Death of Doctor Faustus
Doctor Faustus (play).description: The Tragical History of the Life and Death of Doctor Faustus, commonly referred to simply as Doctor Faustus, is a play by Christopher Marlowe, based on the German story Faust, in which a man sells his soul to the devil for power and knowledge. Wikipedia

Glengarry Glen Ross.label: Glengarry Glen Ross
Glengarry Glen Ross.description: Glengarry Glen Ross is a 1992 American drama, adapted by David Mamet from his 1984 Pulitzer Prize- and Tony-winning play of the same name, and directed by James Foley. Wikipedia

Hapgood (play).label: Hapgood
Hapgood (play).description: Hapgood is a play by Tom Stoppard, first produced in 1988. It is mainly about espionage, focusing on a British female spymaster and her juggling of career and motherhood. Wikipedia

Black Comedy (play).label: Black Comedy
Black Comedy (play).description:
Black Comedy is a one-act farce by Peter Shaffer, first performed in 1965.
The play is written to be staged under a reversed lighting scheme the play opens on a darkened stage. Wikipedia

Bedroom Farce (play).label: Bedroom Farce
Bedroom Farce (play).description: Bedroom Farce is a 1975 play by British playwright Alan Ayckbourn. It had a London production at the Prince of Wales Theatre in 1978. Wikipedia

Ichneutae.label: Ichneutae
Ichneutae.description: The Ichneutae, also known as the Searchers, Trackers or Tracking Satyrs, is a fragmentary satyr play by the fifth-century BCE Athenian dramatist Sophocles. Wikipedia

Ion (play).label: Ion
Ion (play).description: Ion is an ancient Greek play by Euripides, thought to be written between 414 and 412 BC. It follows the orphan Ion in the discovery of his origins. Wikipedia

How I Learned to Drive.label: How I Learned to Drive
How I Learned to Drive.description: How I Learned to Drive is a play written by the American playwright Paula Vogel. The play was premiered on March 16, 1997, off-Broadway at the Vineyard Theatre. Vogel received the 1998 Pulitzer Prize for Drama for the work. Wikipedia

Hay Fever.label: Allergic rhinitis
Hay Fever.description: Allergic rhinitis is a group of symptoms affecting the nose. These symptoms occur when you breathe in something you are allergic to, such as dust, dander, insect venom, or pollen.Causes - Symptoms - Tests - Treatment - Prognosis - Prevention National Library of Medicine
